nav_quadratic_equations: Ecuaciones de Segundo Grado (ax² + bx + c = 0)
intro_p1_definition: Una ecuación lineal es una ecuación matemática que puede representarse mediante una recta en un gráfico. La forma más común es y = ax + b, donde:
intro_list_item1_y: y representa el valor en el eje vertical (ordenadas).
intro_list_item2_x: x representa el valor en el eje horizontal (abscisas).
intro_list_item3_a: a es la pendiente de la recta. Indica cuánto sube o baja la recta. Si 'a' es positivo, la recta sube. Si 'a' es negativo, la recta baja.
intro_list_item4_b: b es la ordenada al origen. Es el punto donde la recta corta el eje y (cuando x = 0).
intro_p2_experiment: Juntos, 'a' y 'b' determinan la posición e inclinación exactas de la recta en el gráfico. ¡En este sitio, podrás experimentar con estos valores para ver cómo afectan la recta!
interactive_graph_instructions: Modifica los valores de 'a' y 'b' a continuación, luego haz clic en "Dibujar la recta" para agregarla al gráfico. Usa "Borrar todo" para limpiar.

quadratic_main_heading: Explorando las Ecuaciones de Segundo Grado
quadratic_intro_what_is: ¿Qué es una ecuación de segundo grado?
quadratic_intro_p1_definition: Una ecuación de segundo grado es una ecuación polinómica de grado 2, que puede escribirse en la forma canónica: ax² + bx + c = 0, donde 'a', 'b', y 'c' son coeficientes reales, y 'a' no es nulo.
quadratic_intro_p2_parabola: La representación gráfica de una función de segundo grado (y = ax² + bx + c) es una parábola. La orientación de la parábola depende del signo de 'a':
quadratic_intro_list_item1_a_positive: Si 'a' > 0, la parábola se abre hacia arriba.
quadratic_intro_list_item2_a_negative: Si 'a' < 0, la parábola se abre hacia abajo.
quadratic_intro_p3_discriminant: El discriminante (Δ = b² - 4ac) juega un papel crucial para determinar el número de soluciones (o raíces) de la ecuación:
quadratic_intro_list_item3_delta_positiv: Si Δ > 0, hay dos raíces reales distintas.
quadratic_intro_list_item4_delta_zero: Si Δ = 0, hay una raíz real doble.
quadratic_intro_list_item5_delta_negativ: Si Δ < 0, no hay raíces reales (sino dos raíces complejas conjugadas).
quadratic_intro_p4_page_purpose: Esta página te permitirá analizar estas ecuaciones y visualizar las parábolas correspondientes.

systems_main_heading: [ES] Systems of Linear Equations & Gaussian Elimination
systems_intro_definition: [ES] A system of linear equations is a collection of two or more linear equations involving the same set of variables. The goal is to find a common solution (a set of values for the variables) that satisfies all equations in the system simultaneously.
systems_intro_example_2x2_desc: [ES] A common example is a system of two equations with two variables (often denoted as x and y):
systems_intro_example_2x2_eqs:
[ES]   a₁x + b₁y = c₁
  a₂x + b₂y = c₂
systems_intro_example_3x3_desc: [ES] Systems can involve more equations and variables, such as a 3x3 system:
systems_intro_example_3x3_eqs:
[ES]   a₁x + b₁y + c₁z = d₁
  a₂x + b₂y + c₂z = d₂
  a₃x + b₃y + c₃z = d₃
systems_intro_solutions_desc: [ES] When solving a system of linear equations, one of three outcomes is possible:
systems_intro_sol_unique: [ES] Unique Solution: There is exactly one set of values for the variables that satisfies all equations. Geometrically, this is where the lines (for 2D systems) or planes (for 3D systems) intersect at a single point.
systems_intro_sol_none: [ES] No Solution: There are no values for the variables that can satisfy all equations simultaneously. Geometrically, this means lines are parallel and distinct, or planes do not share any common intersection point.
systems_intro_sol_infinite: [ES] Infinitely Many Solutions: There is an infinite number of sets of values for the variables that satisfy all equations. Geometrically, this occurs when equations represent the same line (for 2D systems) or when planes intersect along a line or are coincident (for 3D systems).
gaussian_intro: [ES] Gaussian elimination is a systematic method for solving systems of linear equations. It involves transforming the system's augmented matrix into a simpler form (row echelon form or reduced row echelon form) using elementary row operations.

gaussian_row_ops_desc: [ES] The following operations can be performed on the rows of the augmented matrix without changing the solution set of the system:
gaussian_row_op_scale: [ES] Scale: Multiply a row by a non-zero constant (kRᵢ → Rᵢ).
gaussian_row_op_add: [ES] Add: Add a multiple of one row to another row (Rᵢ + kRⱼ → Rᵢ).
gaussian_goal_desc: [ES] The objective is to use these row operations to transform the matrix into row echelon form, which typically has ones on the diagonal (for leading coefficients) and zeros below the diagonal. From this form, the solution can be found using back substitution. Further reduction can lead to reduced row echelon form, where solutions can be read off directly.

gaussian_example_solve_step2_desc: [ES] Step 2: Make the leading coefficient in the second row '1'. We can do this with R₂ / -7 → R₂.
